message: I've been trying to do that without much luck. Seems that South simply does not respect the database router.
Using the latest stable build 0.7.3.
@ptone No, as we're still working them out. I'll get a 0.7.4 release out soonish once everything appears to work
FTR, I've been using South with 1.3 for the past few months as it develops, so it's not that far off
0.7.3 isn't 1.3 compatible in a few respects; there's already a few fixes in the trunk version, so I'd try that first.
@ptone Hey, it started out small. And yes, not entirely, though it is suffering slightly
@andrewgodwin Is there any place where these incompatibilities are listed in summary form?
glad to see your new *ahem* small project isn't taking you entirely away from South
though I'll be doing a lot more work over the summer, and possibly have a GSOC student working on some Django-related stuff for it, we'll see
@andrewgodwin thanks. Is there a good support for multiple databases?  BTW, do I need the south migration table in all the databases?
@zvikico There isn't "good support", no - much like Django, there's a basic level there you need to build on, as every multi-db setup is different.
then you're starting to fall out of South's 90% remit :)
Well, if you want to create the table in the correct database, there's an allow_syncdb method for that.
You shouldn't be creating it in all the databases.
Well, I have a database router which I wrote, and django works fine.
I've got more than two databases...
and, IIRC, you only need a south history table in the default DB
Well, database routers...
it takes models, not table names
Sounds reasonable.
Anyway, thank you for the information.
yeah, the database router is you building on Django :)
You can tell South which database to run against using --database, but it will apply the same migrations and make the same tables in each one
That's really not how Django is working.
if you've got different tables in different databases, you're best off having two separate migration sets and wrapping South's migration commands to change SOUTH_MIGRATION_MODULES
no, allow_syncdb does not work for South
we _could_ support a whole new function or two on database routers, but that would require significant work and remodelling of some of the core
and there's plenty of other things that need doing that affect more people
you can always use the internal parts of South more directly; you can manually tell it to run single migrations, for example
but autodetection is going to get very confused
It's not very clear from the documentation, though. It should be clearly stated that the multi-db is simply not supported.
it is, if you use it in the other ways
e.g. master/slave read/write mode
@andrewgodwin Thanks a lot for that tip! I had the same requirement and wrapping South's migration to change SOUTH_MIGRATION_MODULES worked like a charm, it even works when running tests!
fwiw - I'm using South dev version on a large 1.3 project (with lots of dynamically generated models, no less) with few problems. Another release soon would be cool though :)
Single database though, so totally OT for the thread, I've just realised - sorry! :)
